reviewText:
Machinarium is unique in so many ways, which makes it difficult to write about. It's also one of those games that is best experienced firsthand rather than after reading a spoiler-ridden review. As much as I'd like to lecture on about something that impacted me so greatly, I'm left with very little to work with; but what's there to discuss paints a picture of a masterpiece.

Visually, Machinarium takes a Victorian children's book illustration style and blends it with dystopian psuedo-steampunk imagery. It's not only as striking as that description suggests but it adds layer upon layer to the gameplay and storyline. Characters and scenes are beautifully hand-drawn and painstakingly animated to bring life to the citizens of the eponymous metropolis. When I say life, I mean it metaphorically as the cast are entirely robotic; their endearing movements and actions convince you that they're genuine creatures, acting out of circuitry or as puppets.

The whole game is a juxtaposition. The pure and sweet protagonist stands brightly against the grim, dank underbelly of the city whilst the dark despair of obsolescence and helplessness is often paired with love and hope. There's a great story to be discovered without ever uttering a single word, written or spoken. That alone is a remarkable feat but the characters you meet along the way are just as impressively fleshed. From the musical troupe in need of new instruments to the brutish and bullying pair that serve as antagonists; so many moments will ring in your mind when you reminisce years later, which is a powerful statement.

I don't personally enjoy point and click adventures very often as I find they can sometimes be generic, predictable and require great leaps in logic. There are always exceptions, especially when it comes to LucasArts game, but lumping Machinarium into that category does little to help explain just why it's something every gamer should experience. It's on a par with the bests but ultimately nothing like them except in some key ingredients. The puzzles are frequent and never bordering on torturous like say 7th Guest, but they will certainly test you at times. It's a story-focused experience without sacrificing those times where you need to take a step back and hope for a eureka moment.

There are moments where I wish you could walk across scenes a little faster, but the protagonist's gentle hobbling is endearing and easily forgiven. Puzzles that prove an irritation are quickly overshadowed by the sheer genius of the next. I'd have liked less of the retro-gaming elements but that comes down purely to preference. I can raise minor criticisms but there are no dealbreakers, nothing that will make distract from how compelling it becomes to see through Josef's quest to reunite with his girlfriend. What Machinarium does, it does extremely well.

As with many games of the genre, it's a fairly brief journey, clocking in at around two hours if you're adept. It's not the longest game by any means and the ending is abrupt and slightly underwhelming but it manages not to overstay its welcome. The brevity does nothing to impact a powerful tale that had me smiling at several moments; you can put a value on the length of a game but it's much harder to put a value on something that makes you feel.

reviewText:
I, a robot?

Adventure is only a point-and-click away as Irreverend Opinions reviews Machinarium!

---

The Blurb
A puzzle adventure in a stylised world of robots and amazing music.  A robot that has been abandoned by his city in pieces must pull himself together and return to not only confront some rather bad robots, but save his robot girlfriend in the process.

The Good
The first thing I noticed about Machinarium, as a first impression, is the music.  The soundtrack by Czech composer Tomáš Dvořák[floex.cz] really stands out in the task of impressing a strange new world without alienating the player from what they are engaged in.

Graphically, the art style for Machinarium is quite striking, with hand-drawn animation hauntingly evocative of works by surrealist Jan Švankmajer, and seeming to be another achievement for Dvorský that fans of Amatina Design will be encouraged to see.  With their pencil-and-paper 'living comic' art style, the organic appearance of the background and characters helps to round out the artificial world with a warm and almost human sense, which helps the player to get involved with the characters quite readily.

For an adventure game without dialogue at all, the plot is quite memorable and involving, with the characters having both impact and personality.  By removing dialogue from the game, the designers also allow the game to be accessible to players who do not speak English, using thought bubbles and pictures, authentic instruments and short beeps or buzzes to illustrate what characters are thinking or asking.

Puzzles throughout the game are both thought-provoking and challenging, sometimes requiring the player to think outside the box to complete tasks without pushing for weird feats of skewed logic present in some games of the genre.  Should the game prove to be too much of a bother, an in-built 'hint' system allows players to get some suggestions to how they can complete the task.

The Bad
For some players, the puzzles will be a bit too challenging, though thankfully a short minigame can help to unlock the puzzles if you are more of a mind to do a reflexive shooter than a point-and-click puzzle solve.

Some players have reported having issues with transferring the game from fullscreen to windowed mode, though this seems to be more of a UI confusion than a bug issue.

The Ugly
None to speak of.

Suggestions
Turn out the lights and enjoy the immersive, imaginative world.

The Summary
Well deserving of the awards it has recieved, Machinarium is a beautiful game with something special for art and music lovers, as well as fans of the point-and-click puzzle genre.  10/10.

---

It’s not often that a point and click adventure grabs my attention these days, in fact the only two that come to mind are Back to the Future and Finding Teddy, yet Machinarium had just the right charm to stand out amongst the masses and pull me in.

And it’s a good thing too, because without the adorable robot/steampunkish skin, the precious animations, and fantastic soundscape, Machinarium would just be another generic point and click puzzle game. The puzzles themselves were often convoluted and some just outright infuriated me when I found out what you had to do to solve them. If I had not been so invested in this adorable little robot and watching him move around this world my game time would have ended after about 45 minutes.

If you love what you see in the screenshots, and are not totally averse to the Point and Click genre then I think there’s a ton of enjoyment to be had with Machinarium. However, if you find this genre of game insufferable or don’t find the same charm in the art that I do, then steer clear because there’s nothing here that you’re not expecting.

reviewText:
Short version: 82%Machinarium is a textless point ‘n’ click adventure game set in a robot world with a really memorable design, difficult puzzles, and a simple, yet wonderful story.

Long version:Anamita Design is famous for their adventure games where the entire story is told purely in visuals, without any voices or text. Machinarium is no exception.

The game is set in a strange world, where cyberpunk-style city slums and rust heaps meet very friendly, children’s storybook-like character design and story structure. Even the story is childishly simple, from a certain degree: you are a little “boy” who must save his girlfriend from a band of good-for-nothing hoodlums. These bullies not only managed to throw him out of the city after hurting his mentor(?), but also plan to cause further havoc among the peace-loving citizens.

Machinarium has an interesting difficulty curve. Initially, all scenes are self-contained puzzles, but after a while it switches to traditional point ‘n’ click format. You suddenly have a somewhat decent-sized city to search for items you can use, but it won’t be easy. The world is quite alien despite the somewhat human-like elements, and there are no descriptions anywhere. This can make identifying objects quite tricky sometimes, so prepare to resort to some brute force trial and error.

Despite the difficulty, the game is surprisingly short; if you start it up again knowing all the solutions, you can enjoy the full story in about two hours. As an Anamita game this length is pretty much expected, and you can know that you get a sweet, fun and charming little gem– with a memorable soundtrack– for your money.

reviewText:
Machinarium is one of those cute little Indie designs that, due to it's small team or low budget, has to pick up its boots and survive on its charm alone, and while concise and simplistic, it does that in spades. A sombre meander through a beautifully stylized, decaying robotic and alien world.

Highlights
The reason Machinarium works so well is that it's very simple, what would normally be a flat flash game has been given life with tone, interaction, soundtrack and art style all marrying together to create a truly solid little game.

* The lack of dialogue and the fantastic sound and music, when placed together with the rustic, dystopian art really give the world a strong but still alien character to the world and make you want to explore and see more of it
* Little detailed works like the mini-games for hints add a fun layer of light wonder

Mistakes
* Genuinely none that take away from the game other than perhaps a lacklustre ending

Recommendations
Play time clocks in at 5 hours, and there are better indie titles out there for less than Machinarium, and with more replay value, of which Machinarium has very little, but at £7.49/8.49€/$9.99, it's still a reasonably priced and is a good buy when on sale.

There's also an Amanita Collection, which matches the prices of the separate games, but adds the value of the Machinarium soundtrack for free, but since it's soothing and ambient, but not a particularly amazing soundtrack, buying the titles separately is going to be the better choice for most.

Awesome indie game. Got it from my second Humble Bundle. The hand-drawed graphics and a nicely done Plaid-like soundtrack will take you for a refreshing and original adventure. This is the kind of game that gives me some good hopes about the development of quality videogames the way they were during their golden age in the 90's.

Developer Amanita Design really knocks it out of the park with its latest indie point-and-click adventure – a game that’s so creatively offbeat and impeccably stylish that we’ll forgive the fact that it shakes the dusty book of antiquated adventure games long past in our face at every stretch of the way. Machinarium doesn't pull its punches. It's unabashedly old-school tough, and there are many moments where the adventure can come grinding to a halt while you spend a solid hour agonizing over what random widget needs to be fitted where. Even so, the puzzles littering this troubled mechanical realm are astoundingly designed. The game also sports one of the coolest hint systems we’ve ever encountered. You have to play a side-scrolling shooter mini-game each time you want to unlock the tome that contains elaborate hand-drawn sketches detailing how to attack the tougher puzzles in a given level.Helping a robotic jazz band repair their damaged instruments so they can jam out again, racking up a high score in a pedal bike-powered arcade to gather money for a vending machine, and distilling sunflower seed oil to fix an old-timer’s rusty joints are only a few of the myriad tasks you’ll accomplish en-route to saving the city. Many of the game’s challenges are multi-step affairs that require a mixture of exploration, item hunting, and straight-up puzzle solving.Machinarium’s distinct visual style and seamless animations are etched with a staggering level of detail, and few games come close to possessing the sheer beauty found here. Each setting and the peculiar robotic characters populating this futuristic land is brimming with dark personality. Seeing how different areas of the game, the characters, and the plot itself connect in surprising, circular ways makes the journey all the more wondrous. Even if adventure games aren’t your bag, you’d be remiss to pass up giving this one a spin. It might just change your mind.

At this point this game has been critically aproved but I feel like leaving a positive review anyway. Normally I'm not a fan of point and click adventure games but Machinarium has sold me on the idea of them. Great art design, captivating world, and imersive story that unfolds without even a single word being spoken all build something greater than the sum of their parts. If you like point and click adventure games Machinarium will make a great addition to your collection; If you don't it might just change your mind.

A product from an indie studio, Machinarium is an adventure game and is suitable for Gamers aged 8+.

To start, the gameplay is subtle and can be played easily. The graphics presented are mostly clear and clean in appearance while clues are hidden as a slightly visible easter egg in each scene, typical of an adventure game.

A clean crisp sound of robotic sound effects was immediately noticed and was pleasant. On the eardrums, the musical score was sweet and velvety. Neither overpowered the other making for an enjoyable sound track that gently caressed the inner ear like a lovers whisper.

The mini puzzles could be a bit challenging, but nothing the average gamer couldn't finagle their way through. The mini games were a throwback to the 80's, when a young gamer could spend hours in front of classics such as Space Invaders or Adventure.

Overall, Machinarium performed perfectly and would easily be considered an adventure game classic.

Machinarium is a groovy little adventure game. The puzzles are not too difficult, and fairly logical... you rarely have that awful adventure-game experience where you're moving from room to room, clicking on random stuff, trying to get lucky. The game starts you out slow - one room, one puzzle, and gradually works you up to several rooms with several simultaneous puzzles.

The overall atmosphere is very good... a little robot exploring a run-down robot city. And the sound is fantastic, with a variety of full-length songs and themes for each area you explore.

There's very little not to like, here. The length of this game is about 6-8 hours. Maybe a little less if you're an adventure game junkie. Overall, Machinarium is a finely-tuned gem.

reviewText: Machinarium is an alternate universe puzzle point and click adventure in which you play as a small robot known as Josef who is looking for his missing girlfriend Berta. The adventure starts with you laying in a scrapheap figuring out how to piece yourself together. And once you get past that little puzzle, you quickly realise this is not an easy game... The puzzles are definitely more inline with the difficultly of the 16bit area of video gaming, not that it is a bad thing thing. The difficulty of the game naturally fits in with the aesthetics of the art, one can spend so long on certain puzzles, it gives plenty of time to admire the sheer beauty of the hand drawn art. The puzzles are creative and fresh, with a strong touch of quirkiness and humour with every completion. The music is easy on the ears and integrates with the games deep atmosphere. My criticisms of Machinarium would be that pointer can be a little imprecise, also if you move Josef while he is in tall or shot form, he hobbles along at a tedious pace. And the game does not offer any video settings, on certain monitors it can appear 'boxed'. Besides these minor setbacks, Machinarium is a beautiful work of art and a solid puzzle game full of humour, unique surprises and character. I strongly recommend this one.

Not sure if I had gottent this through a humble bundle purchase or another Steam type bundle.  Decided to finally get around to trying it.  The art style is very cute, and for the most part fits the environment well.  Unfortunately, some of the puzzles are very nonsensical, which tends to happen with point and click type adventures such as this.  Also, the game is extremely finicky about where you can click to use certain things.  The game requires you to be standing in range of anything you can interact with, as opposed to being able to click on an item across screen and have your guy walk across to it.  This is especially frustrating when trying to use items, and you happen to not be standing in the specific spot required.

There are some small arcade type parts that do not really add or subtract from the experience.  A fan of puzzle type games may have more fun with this as opposed to a casual player.  I would have to recommend if you are a more casual player, to be ready to reference a walkthrough if needed to help with some of the more difficult combinations of items / puzzles.

I'm going to say yes to recommending the game, but with reservations.  Pick up when cheap or bundled with other games of this nature.

reviewText:
That awkward moment when a good friend gifts you a game that you're just not that into.

I first played this a few years ago, shortly after it was released and had a wealth of critical acclaim surrounding it, but made the difficult and uncharacteristic decision to abandon it half way through as it was bugging me way too much to be bothered with it anymore. A combination of grindingly slow pacing, tedious, unsatisfying puzzles and downright depressing atmosphere put me off it way too quickly. But after receiving it as a birthday present, I felt I owed it to both the game and my friend to give it another shot and play it through to its entirety. Unfortunately, all that did was further reinforce my opinion that this game really isn't for me.

Playing as a tiny, little robot, in a big, bad robot world, you'll point and click your way through sections of the city of Machinarium as you try to thwart the plans of a nasty gang of bullying, nogoodnik robots who've placed a bomb on the tower of your former place of residence... or workplace, it's hard to tell for sure. But apparently robots and their dwellings are pretty grim. Pretty much from top to bottom, everything feels dingy and bleak, like all hope is lost and everyone is now resigned to living a pitiful existence with no sign of ever getting better. Everything just felt so soul-crushingly oppressive and didn't make me want to stay a moment longer than I needed to, really not a good quality for a game.

Normally dark tones in games don't bother me in the slightest, and if anything, really appeal to me. I felt right at home wandering the wastes of Fallout, or scavenging among the leftover detritus of humanity in S.T.A.L.K.E.R., but this just felt like too much even for me. At least Fallout has its dark humour laced throughout, and S.T.A.L.K.E.R. has its sense of mystery and vague suggestion that the outside world is a better place or people are building towards something better inside the disaster zone. But there's no such optimism here. It isn't even like it's a fictitious dystopia here, more like a way-too-close-to-reality feeling of dire finality and going through the motions. To their credit, the hand drawn art that makes up every part of the game is incredibly well done and feels like a real labour of love, like something much more personal that you don't get in other games. I just wish they had've chosen another direction for the aesthetics and made something less downbeat. Though I guess that's just going to come down to personal opinion more than anything.

Aside from the opening introduction to the controls, there isn't a single line of text or dialogue throughout the game, with everything expressed through animated speech/thought bubbles or observing cues from the world and the robots that fill it. But, again, this only adds to tone. The subdued, mood music and low-rumbling barks and grunts of every other character further drills home how morbid everything feels. Yeah, in case you didn't already get it, I think this game is grim. There's something about Eastern European developers that makes them way too good at capturing those feelings in a game, with a sense that some studios are almost in a race to try and outgrim one another. Well, this feels like it could be their crowning achievement. Yet, even had the overall mood of the game been different, that still wouldn't have helped my issues with the slow crawl of so many parts of the game, or the fact that most of the puzzles felt like a chore to do, either because of the execution once you knew the solution, or finding the solution itself... and then executing it.

I'm a fan of the studio's other works, Botanicula and the Samorost games, and I look forward to more titles along those lines if more point and click games are what they're sticking with. But unfortunately this is one I can't recommend above those and have no wish to ever visit again in future.

I've played much more of this game on a friend's tablet, so don't think this review is limited to the short playtime I have logged on Steam.  I'm severely neutral about this game, which is a shame given how enjoyable its atmoshpere is.  It is a pretty game, with an interesting touch of characterization on your little gizmo.  There are two reasons why I can't quite reccomend this game though, and while they don't make the game bad it definitely makes it worth less than the 10 USD price.

First is a more personal peeve, it's made to immitate old-school point and click adventures in that there's a thread of logic that usually makes sense in the game world but doesn't if the immersion is broken.  That thread of how to progress can feel arbitrary, like the developers have contrived a reason why you can't just do a simple solution here, or why this device's switch is in a nigh-unaccesible alcove.  And that adventure game logic has always peeved me, but it's perfectly fine so long as you're immersed.

Aaaaand that's the two of it: the immersion.  This game has a great soundtrack and needs it, because the gameplay is far from enough to pull (in my experience) the player in.  The tokenism and the obviously contrived puzzles are a big part of it, which encourages players to click around looking for what can and can't be used, but the other part is a bit more subtle.  Your character's competency changes, and that always pulls me out of a game.  Sometimes your character (Read: the game) will do something automatically that in a less-padded puzzle would have required you to hunt for an inventory item to do.  So occasionally I'm looking for what I believe is the last piece and then when I can't find it just rub my inventory against itself and give birth to progress.  That, or the gizmo guy can squeeze into or stretch to reach something that in a previous puzzle would not have been possible.

Two faults, yes, and two major ones that the 10 USD price cannot afford to have.

reviewText:
Machinarium is an adventure game in the classic point & click style. A genre that by now only lives in the indie development scene. Whether that is a good or a bad thing is still up for debate.

You play as a little lovable robot that seems to have been made out of mostly trash. As an entirely mute protagonist, as are every character in the game, mute that is, you experience the entirety of the storyline through little memory bubbles that pop every now and then to explain your connection to a particular item or individual. You may or may not understand them however.

Gameplay is entirely point and click. You click on an object in the world to interact with it and on occasion pick it up. Items you collect can be used to interact with those same objects and occasionally can be combined with other collected items to form a new object. It is all very tried and true having been done this way for ages. Unfortunately Machinarium always keeps around some the failings of this genre. Many times you will find that you have to interact with a very specific part of a larger object with no discernible way to see which small place on the screen you have to click to make it work. The logic of the various puzzles, in true point and click fashion, marches to it's own drummer and if you approach the puzzles without being able to adopt this often bizarre method of thinking you will find your stumped quite often.

Machinarium is quite a pretty game, despite being made entirely in flash it manages to produce a beautiful steampunkish environment that is very pleasing to the eye. Being made in flash however means that the occasional accidental right click can often ruin your day.

All in all Machinarium is a fun little game if you're a fan of adventure point and clicks. It is however not a game that stands out in the genre or makes any attempt at even being playable for someone that is not a fan of the genre already.

I'm a sucker for some good point-and-click gamnes. But when it comes to this one, I can't recommend it.

The art style makes everything extremely difficult to make out one item from another. Somethimes they hvae a VERY subtle glow, but even that isn't hepful. The game mechanics are interesting to say the least. You can only interact with things in your reach, and you can extend or retract your robots body to add height-specific puzzle solving. My complaints with the height changing are extremely lengthy. My main issue with it, is the walking speed. There's time sensitive puzzles you have to do early on in the game. And if you forget to retract your body (or raise it) you end up walking extremely slow. Lo and behold, you find yourself hobbling back to the original point of interest to restart the puzzle.

The game does a terrible job of explaining anything to you, and the controls often feel clunky. Though the game is fun for a little bit, it finds itself repeated quite quickly.

If point-and-click adventure games are your thing, I recommend anything but this game. It wore me out to the point where I don't even want to play any of the other games that do what this is trying to do, better.

The normal price is $9.99 but is 65% off for $3.49 during the winter sale. I can't say it's a waste of money, because it's inexpensive and after an hour or so (give or take based on preference) pays for itself. If you can avoid buying it for full price but still want to pick it up, it's better to get it on sale, or wait for one. Otherwise, I don't feel it's really worth the trouble for $10 (or regional equal to USD)

I really wanted to like this game, but the fact that the game could ruin the experience in many different ways put me off in a very bad way.

This game is amazing in so many ways, and a bit frustrating in others. It is visually gorgeous, with a very well-told story, albeit not a 'talkie'. The music and soundscape is truly masterful, and ranges from passively complimentary ambience to exceptionally crafted interactivity. The game is also quite difficult at times, as most of the puzzles are at least moderately challenging, and the hint and/or solution option usually present a quandary in and of themselves (the solution option just requires a little atari-style minigame, but is illustrated so cryptically as to be useless at times). If you are looking for something casual, this is not your game. Even if you consult the walkthrough, it can still be maddeningly hard. But when you solve puzzles in this game and as the story progressess and you see more of this strange world, all the tenuous stuff is worth it. The drawbacks of this game are glitchiness and obtuse interaction: glitches are glitches, and I need not clarify that other than to say they are not game ruining, but when I say obtuse interaction, I mean that a good portion of the game involves combinatorial or timely interaction with elements that are just not obvious. Case in point: (minor spoiler) in a certain encounter, the robot band's instruments are broken; what to do? Of course you go up a few flights of stairs in a certain direction, disrupt a few robots in very specific ways, accost an owl, and electrocute a cat, then take the cat and bring it over to the band robot dude's didgeridoo and stuff it inside so it can scare the small animal that nothing has indicated was present out of the robot's instrument. If I had not looked that up, I probably could have gone months without knowing what to do with either the cat or the didgeridoo robot-guy. All the same, I don't mind those inconveniences, as the game is an amazing and fantastic experience. I just can't give it the highest of recommendations, despite being extremely fond of it. One of the things that I hate about most adventure games is that the puzzles are ♥♥♥♥ing absurd. When I'm expected to just figure out that I'm supposed to use the duct tape on the cat to get hair and combine that with the glasses frames to create a Groucho Marx disguise to sneak into the party, I'm pretty turned off. That's not a puzzle, it's an exercise in tedious trial and error, and for me, table-flipping frustration.

Machinarium mostly avoids this, and as such I'm willing to say that it, along with Botanicula, hold the title for best adventure game of all time. Seriously! Amanita Design avoid the key pitfalls of adventure game design and substitute that with killer visuals and fantastic music. As far as I'm concerned, Machinarium does everything right.

It's a bit short, and I wont deny that there are a few puzzles that are too esoteric to be praised, but overall I really, really enjoyed myself, which is more than I can say for a lot of games. I'd pick it up.

Tired of the overdone FPS, RPG, or RTS? Enjoy a relaxing time in the game Machinarium where you will be delightfully entertained by a handdrawn environment and interesting bunch of characters. Machinarium is your atypical point and click puzzle solving adventure. You will find yourself, more than once, just pausing to listen to the ambience of the world around you.  With no actual words used by the characters, Machinarium manages to transcend the language barrier, using a pictograph styled language instead. Unlike most of its genre, Machinarium comes with a hint guide within the game, locked by a small minigame each time you reference it. This allows you to avoid tedous frustration that prevails in so many point and click adventures.

If you are looking for a simple game that has many beautiful layers of complexity woven into a succinct plot, Machinarium is the game for you.

Machinarium is a Flash based point and click adventure game that is unique in its execution.  Each area has readily accessable hint and a full walkthrough of the area at the cost of playing a somewhat tedious mini-game to keep you from looking at it unless you're really stuck.  The robot you control can be stretched shorter or taller with a mouse drag which gives you the ability to reach areas you couldn't without it and adds complexity to many of the game's puzzles.  Most of the puzzles are pretty simple and produce, at most, a moderate challenge.

The real appeal of this game though is its art.  Almost everything is made of metal and the way it's drawn and painted gives the abstract looking structures a touch of realism that shows each ones age through how rusted or weathered it looks.  The ambient music helps to set the darkish tone of the game with mechanical and lo-fi sounds. While I'm on the topic of tone despite the dark atmosphere, the character you play as, and many of the ones you meet, are quite peppy and charming which gives an interesting contrast that made me feel as if the robots were living it a different paradigm.

It might just be nostalgia, but I miss adventure games, and I really feel the medium still holds up today; at least on PC's.

Toilet paper, puts it in his mouth. Someone's arm, puts it in his mouth. Traffic cone, puts it in his mouth. Every item to pick up in this game goes right into Josef's mouth. I guess it doesn't affect him, though. I mean, he's a robot. Why couldn't he just put the bullies in his mouth? You are able to change his height in the game, which makes it easier to grab things higher than you. There's a little lightbulb at the corner of the screen, and when you click on it, it tells you what your goal to the level is. I always click on it just to make sure. Right next to it is a picture of a watch-like object. When you click on that, it makes you play a mini game that makes no sense at all. Here's what happens: You're a flying key that shoots pellets trying to avoid hitting the side of a brick wall and spiders. IT MAKES NO SENSE! Other than that, this game is good and it is under my approval! :)

6/10 point-and-click. Visually this thing is killer and a ton of fun to experience. The concept is just very well thought out and the puzzles are clever and frankly some of the smartest I've ever played. Mechanically, this game is just awful at times which is silly since it's a mechanical world (face-palm for dumb pun). It's a flash port so don't expect it to be super well optimized for any system. The thing that just cranked my gears the wrong way was that I would click to go somewhere and realize I had left the robot's body elongated or shortened which makes him travel at half the pace. You can't redirect him back mid-travel, as far as I know you can't speed up the game, and you can't readjust him to normal height while he's walking either making for a lot of headbanging on my desk waiting for the stupid robot to get to the place he needed to go. Other than that, it has a killer aesthetic and a fun dialogue free story which is just fantastic and you should definitely give this game a try if you're at all into these kind of adventures. The docked points were for the time wasting oversights and not for the actual puzzles themselves which were easily some of the best I've ever seen in any game.
